Advanced Incan road-building techniques mean all your infantry move faster.

"That's the last time I take Joe to buy frames with me."
Villagers gather Coin from all sources much faster. Dutch get +2 bank limit.
Arid trees such as Aruacaria. Harvest for Wood.
You are already in a Custom Game.
Commander of the Knights of St. John on Malta.
Leader of a large group of Caribbean pirates.
Leader among the Knights of St. John on Malta.
Famous Ottoman leader known as "the Falcon."
John's uncle. Fat men are usually jolly, but he's just cowardly.
British officer from Virginia. Great things await him.
Build a Trading Post at the Lakota village.
Destroy Warwick's Outpost on Barren Hill.
You may want to bring a significant army with you if you attack the Trading Post.
The only place to build a Trading Post at a Lakota village is in the south.
Bring the White Buffalo from Warwick's pen to the Lakota village.
Destroy Warwick's Trading Post on the Trade Route.
Claim the lost gold on Owl Island.
Find and return the Lakota chief's daughter to the Lakota village to the south.
Herd five wild horses to the Lakota tribe to the south.
Owl Island is located in the northwest. You may want to search the shoreline for a way to get across. Settlers will be able to gather the gold once you are on the island.
Defeat the guards around the White Buffalo's pen to free it, then bring it to the Lakota village on the south end of the Great Plains.
The Lakota chief's daughter may need an escort to be returned safely to the south Lakota village.
Barren Hill is located to the northeast.
Wild horses can be found scattered at various places on the Great Plains.
A second chief has been killed by the Boneguard!
The third chief of the Plains has been killed by the Boneguard. Only two remain.
The fourth tribal chief is gone. We must complete our mission before the last chief is killed.
The fifth chief has fallen. We have failed.
The Great White Buffalo is sacred. Rescue it from Warwick and return it to the Lakota village.
You have done it! You have won the respect of the people of the Great Plains.
Earn 10,000 Experience before the Circle kills all five Chiefs.
Earn Experience to help the people of the Great Plains.
A chief among the Great Plains Native Americans.
A mysterious white animal. Servant of the Circle or beast of legend?
Destroy Warwick's navy and his Town Center.
Destroy the three Boneguard outposts before Warwick's navy reaches Lake Erie.
Washington's Imperial navy will be a great help in destroying Warwick's ships. Once the enemy ships are destroyed it will be easy to take a land army in to attack Warwick's Town Center.
Less than a mile distant. I can hear them.
We need to train an army and attack the British from our side.
Try and keep up the attacks, Ká:nien -- the British keep retreating to defend themselves.
Train an army and attack the British from the south side.
Use forces from the north and south sides to destroy the British Town Center,
Destroy all the British buildings to unite Ká:nien and Nonahkee.
If the British attack the Haudenosaunee, you may need to attack from the south side to draw attention. Start gathering resources to build a Barracks and a Stable to train units from.
You can train Mantlets out of the Trading Post in the Haudenosaunee village. Mantlets are excellent unit for taking down buildings.
Advance to the Fortress Age and build an Artillery Foundry.
Remember you will need a reserve of Food and Coin to advance to Fortress Age.
This is the only remaining daughter of the Lakota Chief. She has a great personality.
We must gain the respect of the people of the plains before all of their chiefs are killed by the Boneguard!
The Lakota people will join you!
One of the tribal chiefs has been killed! We must hurry.
Left-click to select a target location.
A mountainous tree such as spruce or aspen. Harvest for Wood.
A mountainous tree such as spruce or aspen. Harvest for Wood.
Defend the colony at all costs.
Defend your Town Center for 15 minutes.
Improve your Walls and Outposts to hold off the Cherokee attacks. Train military as fast as you can! You can send more units and resources from your Home City.
Escort the refugees back to the colony.
Any refugees that make it back to the fort will arm themselves and become Skirmishers to help defend the colony.
Would you like to copy up your AI saved games?
Destroy Warwick's Town Center inside his stronghold.
Destroy Warwick's Trading Post at the Comanche village.
You cannot train Settlers. Capture Supply Wagons and move them to your Town Center to get more resources. But do not wait too long -- Warwick's stronghold grows more powerful over time.
The Comanche village is located to the northeast.
To collect resources from a Supply Wagon, defeat all of a Wagon's escort guards, then move the Wagon near your Town Center.
To collect resources from a Supply Wagon, maintain more units around the Wagon than your opponent, then move it near your Town Center.
To capture a supply wagon, we must defeat the escort guards around it.
Bring the captured supply wagon back to our town center.
We must drive this captured supply wagon back to our town center.
Bring John and Ká:nien to the main Cherokee village to negotiate a peace.
Establish a new colony and defeat the British.
Use your army and the Mercenaries you have to destroy the special Cherokee War Huts. War Huts are different from the Cherokee villages.
Select John and Ká:nien and have them move to the only Cherokee village. The flare indicates where this village is. If John or Ká:nien are down you will need to revive them first.
Use the Covered Wagon to build a Town Center. You will need to start training a pretty good size force because the British are going to push back with a force of their own.
Defeat the Cherokee war parties and negotiate peace.
Meeting place for all the Cherokee chiefs and warriors.
This wagon is carrying Food. Move it to your Town Center.
This wagon is carrying Wood. Move it to your Town Center.
This wagon is carrying Gold. Move it to your Town Center.
This wagon is carrying all resources. Move it to your Town Center.
Help destroy the British on your side of the river.
You will need to move fast and destroy all the British units that are attacking the French. What you save will be yours to use to destroy the British across the river.
Help the French defeat the British.
Find and destroy the British Fort Command building.
The British Fort Command is in the center of the British Fort. They are built up as much as the French are so you will need sizable forces to attack their Fort.

Grants free improvements that increase the combat ability of Walls, Outposts, Blockhouses, Forts, War Huts, and Nobles' Huts.
Surgeons are now available at the Cathedral.
With this upgrade, 3 improvements become available: Fortified Outposts (or Blockhouses), Cannon Bastions (towers), and Star Forts.
Enter adjustment values for each side of the map (in meters).
Click this button to build a new Covered Wagon in the New World.

A swampy tree such as tupelo or cypress. Harvest for Wood.
Failed to connect to game servers.
A Cherokee horse archer. Good against cavalry.
Blah blah blah this is an objective that is long enough to fill up a second line on the objective dialog, so I can debug the problems it has.
He sent his soldiers here, asking for you, promising silver and horses if we would turn you over to him. We sent him away.
I fear more warriors are gathering at the war camps.
Then maybe it's time we took the fight to them.
Stuart, you stay here with the other women.
Yes, I think my skills are best put to use here.
The British are defeated! The base is ours!
Get that covered wagon to safety! We'll use it to build a new town center.
The only way to your sister's village is through the British.
The British are attacking the village. We should attack from our side now!
Sir, one of our scouts has spotted a British fort.
Kills treasure guardians in one shot.
Fire on a target with all guns!
Ships 26 Roger's Rangers (Skirmishers) from the frontier.
The Ottomans have mustered the mighty Tufanci Corps!
Ships 8 Black Watch Highlanders from the homeland.
Ships 10 of the famed Wild Geese (Harquebusiers) from Ireland.

"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."
"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."

Take Black's uncle to our western fort. He will tell me where the Fountain of Youth is before he dies.
Get this supply wagon back to camp. We're going to need the resources to attack that fort.
We're too late. Warwick's fort is too well defended now.
Fine job men. We've destroyed Warwick's fort in time
We have all the settlers we're going to get. For resources we'll have to steal some of Warwick's supply wagons.
If we don't get that fort down in a hurry it will be too well defended to destroy.
Deliver Home City Shipments to this building.
Home City Shipments will arrive at this building.
Your Explorer has just set foot on the shores of the New World.
To move your Explorer, you must first select him. Left-click the Explorer to select him now.
Remember, left-click to select a unit.
Now, with the Explorer selected, right-click on the ground near the flag to move him.
Remember, after units have been selected, right-click to move them.
Your soldiers have disembarked and are ready for your orders.
To select all the Musketeers at once, drag a box around them.
Remember, left-click and hold in the main game window, then drag a box around a group to select them.
Perfect! Now, right-click the ground near the flag.
The Musketeers have joined your Explorer, and you are now ready to begin exploring.
Select all four units by dragging a box around them.
Now right-click the ground near the next flag to move further inland.
Your units are nearing the edge of the screen.
Moving your cursor to the edge of the screen will scroll the view in the main game window.
Try this now. Scroll the view to the left until you see the next flag.
Remember, to scroll the view, move the cursor to the very edge of the screen.
Move your Explorer and the Musketeers to the next flag.
As your units move deeper into the wilderness, notice that more and more of the landscape is revealed.
Once your units have explored an area, you will always be able to see the terrain, but you will only be able to see enemy troops if you have units near them.
The Town Center is the first building in your new colony.
When a game begins, you will receive several Settlers and crates of resources at your Town Center.
Resources are used to construct additional buildings and train soldiers.
Your Settlers will immediately start gathering resources from the crates, but you can redirect them if you like.
Try this now. Select a Settler.
Now right-click on one of the flashing trees.
Good job. The Settler will now gather Wood from the tree.
Settlers can also gather Food from animals and Mills, and Coin from Mines.
You'll need to gather all three resources if your colony is going to survive.
That sound, and the flashing Shipment icon, indicate that you may now send a Shipment from the Home City.
Click on the flashing Home City button now.
During a game of Age of Empires III, visit the Home City now and then to send Shipments of resources, Settlers, or soldiers.
The timer above the Mini Map at the lower left of the screen shows how long it will take until you advance.
While you're waiting to advance, click the flashing button to return to the New World, and continue gathering resources and exploring.
You have reached the Commerce Age!
Build a Barracks to help defend your colony.
Now place the Barracks somewhere near your Town Center.
It would be wise to train some additional soldiers to protect the colony.
For the purposes of this tutorial, you have been given some extra resources.
Now click the flashing Musketeer button five times.
You are now training a small group of Musketeers.
Continue to gather resources and explore.
That sound means your Musketeers are ready -- and just in time too!
Spanish cavalry are on the way to raid your colony!
To attack the cavalry, select the Musketeers, then right-click the enemy units.
Remember, to attack an enemy, select soldiers, then right-click the enemy units.
You have defeated the enemy cavalry and successfully defended the colony!
Congratulations! You're now ready to go on to the second tutorial, called "Try a Game."
Cover Mode. Extra protection from ranged units.
He won't trouble your Iroquois (Haudenosaunee) friends again.
He's gone west towards Lake Huron, with a handful of traitors.
Ally with any other Haudenosaunee in the area.
You are already allied with Nonahkee's village. There may be other Haudenosaunee in the area that could help you defeat the British.
Warwick's Outposts are located along the canyons the Supply Wagons travel.
Stop the Cherokee attackers from destroying the village to the southwest.
Respond quickly to try and save the village from the Cherokee attackers. Any survivors will join your cause.
The Cherokee are attacking that village. We should help them!
I don't know but they're not peaceful anymore! Prepare the defenses! We have to hold off the Cherokee until reinforcements arrive.
We're too late. They've destroyed the entire village.
But she decides who she loves, and I will not come between you.

Allows you to send the Master Miner, who advances you to Commerce Age and improves your Mine gathering rate.
The Lakota Tokala Soldier Society arrives at your Town Center to help fight your enemies. You get 1 Tokala Soldier for every 3 minutes of game length.
Allows you to send the Philosopher Prince, who advances you to Commerce Age and makes archaic units (Longbowmen and Pikemen) better.
Allows you to send the Adventurer, who advances you to Commerce Age and improves your Explorer's hitpoints and the line of sight of cavalry and infantry.
Allows you to send the Cavalier, who advances you to Commerce Age and increase cavalry hitpoints.

Allows you to send the Engineer, who advances you to Industrial Age and increases artillery hitpoints.
Allows you to send the King's Musketeer, who advances you to Commerce Age and improves your infantry's hitpoints.
Allows you to send the Naturalist, who advances you to Commerce Age and improves your hunting and livestock gathering rate.

Allows you to send the Gentleman Pirate, who advances you to Industrial Age and increases Mercenary hitpoints.

Allows you to send the Master Miner, who advances you to Commerce Age and improves your Mine gathering rate.
This tech doesn't do anything yet!
Upgrades this Trade Route to use Stagecoaches, which can deliver resources, move faster and provide greater line of sight.
Upgrades this Trade Route to use Trains, which deliver resources faster and provide greater line of sight.
If the Russians can move their artillery past the mountains, we will not be able to stop them!
You don't have a cliff selected
You don't have a cliff type selected
Trading Posts are cheaper, stronger and gain an attack.
Diverse tropical trees including palms and strangler figs. Harvest for Wood.
Aztec warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Carib warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Cherokee warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Comanche warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Cree warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Inca warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Haudenosaunee warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Lakota warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Maya warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Nootka warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Seminole warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Tupi warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Do you wish to leave the game you are currently in?
Another fireship -- it's coming in to ram!
The pirate has a base on this island -- bombard it!
After our colony gets started we'll need to find a way to sail through these islands, Captain.
What's this? My dock is under attack?
We have all the navigation charts we need to sail to the New World!
Try to destroy the fireships from range!
We can transport some settlers to a nearby island to gather all of the resources if we run low here.
The pirate has defeated our entire expedition. We are lost.
A second town center built on another island could be very useful.
Find and collect three Navigation Charts.
Use your ships to attack the pirate ships discovered near your starting location. Try to destroy the pirate's Fireships before they can ram your ships.
Your Covered Wagon can be used to build a Town Center. Find a place to build your Town Center that has plenty of Food, Wood and Coin nearby.
The Navigation Charts are guarded. Make sure you have an army when scouting for them. The Navigation Charts are just like Treasures, so Heroes and Settlers can pick them up.
The Spanish dogs have imprisoned some Aztecs to mine gold for them.
One of the prisoners has shown us the way to the Aztec village.
We must construct a trading post and form an alliance with the Aztecs.
Our covered wagon has arrived. We must use it to build a town center near the trading post.
We must help the Aztecs defend their temples against the Spanish until the large Aztec army arrives.
We can add to our fighting force by freeing the prisoners working on mines outside the village.
The Spanish have destroyed one of the Aztec temples.
The Spanish have destroyed two Aztec temples -- we must not let the last one fall!
The Spanish have destroyed the last Aztec temple -- the village is doomed.
The Spanish base is too strong to assault with the forces we have now.
We welcome you in our battle against the Spanish.
I will send a runner to Tenochtitlan to request an army of Aztec warriors. We must protect the temples in my village until they arrive.
My runner reports the great Aztec army is on its way.
The great Tenochtitlan Aztec army will be here soon - we must protect our temples!
The Tenochtitlan army is almost here -- protect the temples!
The Aztec army has arrived! Wipe the Spanish from this town!
The Spanish are on the run. The village is saved.
Kill the Spanish guards guarding the prisoners around the Mine.
Build a Trading Post at the Aztec village.
At least one Aztec Temple must remain standing.
Find and destroy the Spanish Town Center.
The prisoners may help you if you free them from the Spanish.
The only place to put a Trading Post is at the south end of the Aztec village.
A ship has dropped off a Covered Wagon in the village. Use the Covered Wagon to build your Town Center.
In 15 minutes an Aztec army will arrive to help. You will need a strong army to protect the Temples. Freeing some more prisoners working outside the village would help your chances.
The Aztec army can help you eliminate the Spanish Town Center. The Spanish attacks have been coming from the northeast. You may need Mortars to help destroy the Spanish buildings.
TEAM Livestock fatten faster. (For Indian allies, livestock generate more experience points. For Japanese allies, livestock generate more resources when tasked to Shrines.)
We need to take out the Boneguard outposts before Warwick's navy overruns our base.
Reinforcements from Washington! On to the second outpost!
Warwick's navy is growing in power. We need to take down those outposts.
Washington has sent us transports! We can use them to assault the far base.
Warwick's navy is here! We can't defend against that kind of firepower!
If we don't get those outposts down, Washington will never send us help.
Warwick's navy is done! Concentrate on the main base.
Warwick's base is destroyed! Focus our forces on his navy.
Excellent work men! Warwick's forces are defeated but it would seem he has escaped.
Build a Trading Post near the natives and they will ally with us.
Send out a few scouts to see if there are any more natives in the area.
There are many Native Americans in this area. Find them and build Trading Posts near them to make an alliance. In the Commerce Age you can train their warriors to help you fight.
The Ottoman Fort is very strong. Getting to the Fortress Age and training Mortars at your Artillery Foundry will greatly help with this task.
Knights of Malta that throw flaming hoops at Janissaries.
Warships hitpoints and line of sight increased.
All unique Ottoman Mosque improvements cost 60% less.
These pirates have maps and navigational charts that can help us get through this maze of islands and reefs.
A second Town Center may allow you to expand your economy more quickly.
The rest of the prisoners may also be guarded by the Spanish but will help you if you free them.
Rams anything on the water and explodes.
These Weapon Caches are being used to support the Ottomans.
Kill the guards near the Fixed Gun.
Destroy the Circle's base to the east of the Fixed Gun.
Build a Trading Post at the Native village.
It may be possible to capture the Fixed Gun if the guards are taken out quickly.
The Fountain of Youth is sturdy. It may take a combination of attacks from Fire Ships and other means to destroy it.
The captured Fixed Gun is powerful against any enemy target, and will also help destroy the Fountain of Youth. To use it, select it and right-click on a target.
Seminole warriors and improvements will be useful as you fight to destroy the Fountain of Youth.
Enormous fixed gun. Can be captured if no enemy units are in the area.
Source of water for the Lake of the Moon. Is it magical?
Tropical tree with soft lumber. Harvest for Wood.
Elite musketeer of the Circle of Ossus.
Ship carrying massive amounts of Coin, but has no attack.
Be careful around those janissaries. They are particularly strong against cavalry.
We've lost the fort! Everyone retreat!
Start with Trading Posts unlocked. Best units: Lancers, Pikemen.
Starts with some Mercenaries unlocked in Home City. Best units: Musketeers, Crossbow.
Do not let the Command Post be destroyed.
You have lots of resources. To keep the Ottomans at bay you will need to train many units. Improving your units at the Barracks and other buildings may also be a big help.
Great Bombards are artillery. Cavalry is your best unit to destroy artillery but be careful; Janissaries are just as good at destroying cavalry.
You have been invited to join Clan %s. Do you wish to accept?
Banks cost less and have more hitpoints.

Player Is Selecting Home City Building
Food must be scarce where the Turks have built their Fort. Destroying their Fishing operation will decrease their Food production.
Bombard Mode. Allows cannon to fire and move slowly.
Sir, we've spotted the Turks' fishing operation.
Ah ... destroying their fishing dock should make them hungry.
Left-click to place shallow. Right-click to remove shallow. Rotate with mouse wheel. Press ESC to cancel.
A shallow must be placed on river before creating.

Move the Explorer to the flag.
Move the Musketeers to the flag.
Select the Explorer and the Musketeers.
Move the Explorer and the Musketeers to the next flag.
Scroll the view until you see the next flag.
Move everyone to the next flag.
Move the Covered Wagon to the flag.
Send a Settler from the Home City.
Left-click the Explorer to select him.
With a unit selected, right-click somewhere to move the unit to that location.
To select multiple units, left-click and hold, then drag a box around them.
To move units, select them, then right-click the location where you want them to go.
To scroll the view in the main game window, move the pointer to the edge of the screen.
Select the Covered Wagon, then click the "Build Town Center" button, then left-click to place the Town Center.
Select your Settlers, then right-click on a tree.
If you are still in the main game view, left-click the Home City button. Then left-click the Settler icon to send Settlers to the New World.
Select the Explorer and the Musketeers, and move then into unexplored areas.
Select a Settler, then left-click the Barracks button, then left-click somewhere in the main game window to place the Barracks.
Select the Barracks, then left-click the Musketeer button five times.
Select your Musketeers, then right-click the enemy cavalry. Musketeers are good against cavalry, and should easily defeat them.
Player Sends a Home City Shipment
Thank you friends! Please, make yourselves welcome to anything you need in Havana.
Stolen gold -- we should send some settlers over to gather it.
I hear you've done quite a bit of good here, Morgan. Now I want you to do a favor for me.
This native boy next to me needs safe passage back to his family on that nearby island.
Find the natives that stole his canoe. Once you have it, use it to get to the island.
Sorry Morgan, you're not ready to take a trip with me.
My ship will be ready soon, Morgan. Get back to work and maybe you'll be on it when it is.
Gain 8,000 Experience before Lizzie sails to Florida.
Stop the raiding Native Americans from attacking the settlers of Havana.
Your starting army is big enough to defeat the Native Americans to the west.
Reopen trade with the rest of Cuba by building a second Trading Post.
The Cubans have one Trading Post already. Follow the Trade Route to find a spot to build them a second Trading Post.
Find and gather the stolen gold.
The Gold has been taken by Native Americans. Find their village and you will likely find the stolen Gold.
Return the lost herd to Havana's Livestock Pen.
These thirsty cows have wandered off so looking for them where they can get water is probably a good idea.
Build the first Stable in Havana.
A Stable will give you Experience and help the Cubans. Cavalry will also help you beat the Carib Blowgunners.
Take Lizzie's Native American friend to his family on the nearby Island.
The boy lives on the southeast island. Caribs have stolen his canoe near there. He must not be harmed while helping to get him home.
Morgan needs a ride to Florida. If you raise his Experience enough, Lizzie will give him a ride. The Secondary Objectives below will help you.
Impress Lizzie to get a ride to Florida.
You may want to send your Explorer out into the wilderness to reveal the map and find more resources.
Consider training more Settlers at your Town Center to improve your economy.
Remember, more Settlers can be trained at the Town Center. Select the Town Center, then left-click the Settler button.
Consider putting your Settlers to work gathering resources.
If you want to gather more resources, select your Settlers, then right-click on Trees, Deer, or Mines.
You have found a Silver Mine. If you need Coin, you can task your Settlers on the Mine to gather it.
You have found a Treasure. If you kill the Bear guarding the Treasure, you could send your Explorer to collect it.
To collect a Treasure, select your Explorer, then right-click on the Treasure. All of the Treasure's guardians must be dead.
You have discovered a Native American village!
If you build a Trading Post on the Trading Post site near the village, you will ally with the Haudenosaunee.
That sound means you have discovered a Trade Route!
If you build Trading Posts at the Trading Post sites along the route, you will earn extra Experience.
A Shipment is ready in the Home City!
Return to the Home City and use your Shipments to send additional Settlers, soldiers, or resources.
It would be wise to advance as soon as you have enough Food.
If you advance, you will be able to build additional buildings, train soldiers, and purchase new improvements.
Consider building a Barracks so you can defend your colony.
Building a Barracks will let you train Musketeers and other soldiers.
Consider training Musketeers in your Barracks to defend your colony.
If you build a Stable, you can train cavalry to fight alongside your other soldiers.
Remember, you can build a Stable to train additional cavalry types.
If you're having trouble finding more animals to hunt, consider building a Mill.
Task Settlers on your Mill, and they will gather Food.
You have located the enemy colony!
Send your soldiers to raid the enemy Settlers and Houses -- but be careful not to get too close to his Town Center.
If you advance to the Industrial Age, you could build Mortars to destroy the enemy Town Center.
To advance to the Industrial Age, gather more Food and Coin.
You should build an Artillery Foundry and train Mortars to destroy the enemy colony.
Mortars are the perfect unit for destroying enemy buildings. Train Mortars at your Artillery Foundry.
You now have Mortars. Train some extra units to protect the Mortars, then attack the enemy colony.
If you advance to the Imperial Age, then you will unlock extremely powerful improvements.
You have saved enough resources to advance to Imperial Age!
Use your Mortars to destroy the enemy Town Center!
The island off the eastern coast was a place of ritual ceremonies for the Natives. Wonder if they left anything of value behind?

Train two additional Settlers while exploring the New World.
You can train more Settlers at your Town Center, if you have enough Food. You will need eight Settlers to complete the objective. Hunt animals for Food, or send Food from your Home City.

To advance to the Commerce Age, select the Town Center, left-click the Age Advancement button, and then choose a politician. To advance, you will need 500 Food. Food may be gathered from animals or Mills.
To advance to the Fortress Age, you need 500 Food and 250 Coin. Keep training Settlers at your Town Center. Don't forget to build more Manors to support your population.
Build an Artillery Foundry to train Mortars. Mortars are good at destroying buildings but they need to be protected with other units. When you have a large army, attack!

You start with one of the four Trading Posts. The opposing railroad company starts with one as well. Do not leave your Trading Posts undefended. The other company may try to destroy it.
Hold Trading Post sites until the "Four of a Kind" timer runs out.
Remember you can travel from Trading Post to Trading Post once the train is running. Garrison your men in one Trading Post to ungarrison out of another.

Artillery are the best type of units to use against large buildings, but be careful to protect them from enemy cavalry.

Well done, men, but I fear Sahin will be back. We'll need reinforcements.

Get the troops over there and take out those bombards.
Sir, the bombards are destroyed, but more ships are expected.
Yes my lord. Send the cavalry through the fort and wipe out those bombards.
That's the last of the bombards.
Excellent work, men. We have defeated the Falcon ... for now.

Fire with both shotgun barrels for heavy damage to infantry, cavalry or guardians.

You should move your settlers to the top of the hill quickly. Gather all the wood piles near the Community Plaza to light it. Your only settlers are in the village north. If you lose them, you will not light the fire.

The Knights of St. John call for a New World crusade! You receive a Shipment of 8 Hoop Throwers from Malta, and all Hoop Throwers are improved. This use of trained personnel means all your other units have fewer hitpoints from now on.
Rodelero and Pikemen hitpoints increased, but speed reduced.
Overworking your serfs to meet the silver tax burden reduces their health, decreasing their hitpoints. However you get Crates of 100 Coin for each minute the game has lasted so far.
Collecting as many of these treasures as we can will give us more resources.
All Mercenaries gain custom weapons. Mercenary attack increased. But, all your buildings now cost significantly more to construct.
Now we must lead the great white buffalo to the Lakota village near where we first arrived.

Collect all the Treasures on the map.
The X icon on the Mini Map indicates the location of hidden Treasures. Explorers, Settlers and some Heroes can collect them. Be careful, the Ottomans may be around.
Building that can be used to defend the frontier.
Morgan, the Ottomans have landed -- a thousand janissaries, led by Sahin the Falcon!
Alain Magnan still commands the knights, and he says we must hold them at the beach. We'll make our stand here.
Defensive structure to defend the Fort from attacks.
This building has crops around it. You need to allow more space.
Moves the Arsenal to the Commerce Age and enables more powerful Arsenal improvements.
To advance to the Industrial Age, you need 1000 Food and 500 Coin. If the Mines near your town run out, send Settlers to more distant ones, or build a Estate.
The story of why my family first came to the New World begins with the attack on Malta, the last stronghold of a dying order of Crusader-Knights.
This much is fact -- my ancestor Morgan Black was with the Knights of St. John when they defended the island from Sahin and the Ottomans.
The rest ... well, like most family stories, it's hard to separate the truth from the legend.
With Alain Magnan dead and the Fountain destroyed, the Circle of Ossus had nothing left in the New World.
Sahin knew the Europeans were carving out empires in the Americas. He realized that the Ottomans were as much relics of the past as the Knights of St. John.
Lizzie had lost her Spanish gold, and it would be several years before she really forgave Morgan.
I'm not sure if she was really my great-great-grandmother, but folks say I have a pirate's temper.
Was there something special about the Fountain's water?
All I know for sure is the Circle would return to find out.
Everyone always said Morgan's grandson John Black had a lot more enemies than he had friends.
But one man, a Mohawk named Ká:nien, always stood by his side -- even if the two did have a friendly rivalry.
I don't know exactly what happened on the mountain that day. But my grandfather wasn't the type to go down without a fight.
John Black may have made a lot of enemies in his life, but he died a hero. He knocked the Circle back on their heels so hard it would take them decades to recover.
By spring, Ká:nien had returned to his village. Life went on, just as it had for years.
Except that his sister had given birth to John's son.
And though the Russians were gone, Ká:nien knew other white men would follow.
But until then, he would live, work, and help raise his sister's son ...
John's sacrifice did not go unnoticed. My family was rewarded by the British government -- and later, the Americans. By the standards of those days, we got rich.
Those were eventful years. We pushed the frontier to the horizon -- building, expanding, heading west.
My father Nathaniel was a patriot, but not much of a businessman. By the time he left the company in my hands, the Black family fortune had dried up.
And so we come to my part of the story.
What I remember most about that day are the smells - black powder, sweat, and too much death.
Or maybe all I was smelling was that damn Beaumont.
Was the Fountain's water worth it all? I never found out.
What I did know was that the Circle had stored a lot of treasure in the Ossuary over the years.
Uncle Ká:nien said we shouldn't profit from the cult's blood money, but most of the gold came from those Spanish treasure ships Morgan and Lizzie sank.
The way I figured it, the Circle of Ossus owed the Black family a little something.Don't you agree?
During this tutorial, if you're ever confused about what to do next, click on the flashing Objectives button.

Morgan set sail for Florida, but he hadn't counted on the hurricane.
It was like no storm the knights had ever seen. It swept across the Caribbean with a vengeance, leaving fragile colonies in ruins.
But for Morgan, if serving the Knights of St. John meant sailing to the New World, he was ready for whatever challenges awaited him there.

Texas is an open plain with scattered low cliffs. Two Trade Routes, each with two Trading Post sites, cut through the center of the map, separating the teams. There will always be at least two Comanche or Apache settlements, and sometimes three. Expect attacks from every side.
Chase Beaumont and the Boneguard out of the mines.
I need to get help from the native villages.
Beaumont has run further into the mines. Let's go after him.
Some native warriors have come to help us.
Stagger Mode. Extra spacing helps units avoid cannon fire.
Trample Mode. Units do extra trample damage while moving slower and taking extra damage in the process.
TEAM Musketeer and Grenadier hitpoints increased. For Indian and Japanese allies, Sepoy and Ashigaru hitpoints increased.
TEAM Houses, Manors, Shrines, and Villages build much faster.
TEAM Villagers gather all Wood faster. Trees last longer.

Teams are separated by the mighty Amazon River. Trade Routes and Natives may be separated... or maybe not. Tupi, Zapotec or Maya live deep in the rain forests. Build a navy to control the river, and control the map -- but keep an eye out for enemy Outposts and cannon on the shores.

A large Inca city dominates the Andes; control the city, and you will easily control the map. Neutral Huari Strongholds are scattered throughout the area, presenting challenges for unwary explorers. Three Trading Post sites. Seek out herds of Llamas for an early boost of food.

The islands of the Caribbean support only a few animals, but the ocean offers a bounty of fish. Palm trees provide plenty of Wood for constructing ships.\n \nYou will share an island with your teammates. There will always be an additional island with a Trade Route. Carib settlements are scattered across all the islands.

The southeast coast of North America has plenty of resources and extra Crates. The ease of naval transport and lack of cliffs means you are never too far from your enemy. A Trade Route runs along the coast with four sites for Trading Posts.\n \nThis is the home of the Cherokee, who will always have two villages on the map. Sometimes you may encounter one or two Seminole villages as well.

A vast swamp where dry land is at a premium. You can only build on solid ground, but armies can travel across the wetlands, so beware of unexpected ambushes.\n \nCherokee and Seminole villages occupy islands through the middle of the map.

Fight around the outside of a large freshwater lake. Control of the single long Trade Route is crucial. Huron, Cheyenne, or Cree villages ring the lake. Resources, including fish, are plentiful.\n \nBuild too close to the shore without controlling the water, and you risk having your town shelled by enemy ships late in the game. Sometimes the lake may be frozen over, presenting a different tactical challenge.

Wide-open spaces, large herds of Bison to hunt, plentiful Mines, and as many as six Cheyenne and Comanche villages offer a wide variety of potential strategies. The Trade Route will have three Trading Post sites.\n \nControl the more dense forests near the edges of the map to supplement your late-game wood gathering, or rely on the scattered clumps of trees out on the plains.

Each team will have an easily-defended Huron village; the fight will be for control of the four Trading Post sites along the single central Trade Route.\n \nLakes and low stone walls provide natural barriers and choke points. Search the isles off the coast for hidden coin mines.

Pampas is a long plain divided by a river with several crossing points. You and your allies are initially separated by the river, but the exact placement of your starting towns varies widely. There are always four Trading Post sites. Expect to find a number of Mapuche or Tupi villages.

No Natives, but six Trading Posts. To ensure a steady supply of Wood, stay near the coast.\n \nA central lake offers tactical opportunities, and may restrict movement along the western side of the map. The lake is not present in Free for All games.

Your team occupies one mountain range and your opponents the other. The victors will be the ones that can control the central valley and the choke points. Forests and Treasures are more heavily concentrated in the center of the map.\n \nThe Cheyenne and Comanche have ventured up into the mountains, and may prove to be useful allies.

In this resource-heavy region, you will start with an extra random economic building in addition to your Town Center. Building Outposts near the local Cree and Huron villages may help control sections of the map.

A twisting Trade Route winds its way through this barren, desolate region. Many cliffs and canyons create choke points. Resources can be difficult to find, though sometimes there are rich ore deposits in the center of the map. Search for Apache, Maya, or Navajo villages on the edge of the map.

The Central America rain forests are home to many Treasures. Each player will start with a nearby Zapotec or Maya village. Use your ships to control the land on your side, or try to build a dock on the far shore and control both coasts.\n \nThe dense forests mean you will never run short of Wood, and herds of Tapir and Capybara offer unusual hunting opportunities.

Your enemy’s towns are close, so be on your guard. Cross the river to the north-west where you will find an abundance of valuable treasures as well as large gold deposits. The Trade Route will be hard to completely control, with each team having access to one Trading Post site. Cree or Nootka villages can be found north of the river, both offer valuable improvements that will be helpful in this harsh, but beautiful region.

language.string: In the late sixteenth century, the Knights of St. John defended their last stronghold on the Mediterranean island of Malta from an Ottoman invasion.
As Sahin is driven from Malta, Morgan and his men regroup and prepare to push the surviving Ottomans from their camps.
Seeking to beat the Ottomans to the mysterious Lake of the Moon, Morgan sails for the New World ... but is forced to make an unexpected stop.
Morgan catches up with Sahin in the jungles of Central America - but are the Ottomans too powerful to defeat?
With the Ottomans defeated in the New World, Morgan and his men head into the jungle, seeking the location of the Lake of the Moon from the Aztecs - only to encounter new enemies.
Morgan heads for Florida, hoping to beat the Spanish to the Lake of the Moon, but a hurricane drives his ships off course, forcing him to land in Cuba.
Morgan sails for Florida with the pirate Lizzie, hoping to catch up with the Spanish conquistador Delgado before he reaches the Lake of the Moon.
Morgan, Lizzie, and Sahin press onward to the Lake of the Moon. Has Alain betrayed the Knights of St. John?
By the middle of the eighteenth century, many thriving colonies had been founded in the New World. But European conflicts would soon explode in the Americas ...
With the Cherokee driven off, John and Ká:nien assemble their men in the colony and prepare to counter-attack.
Stuart has been kidnapped, and John suspects his family's old enemies, the Circle of Ossus. The mercenaries head north, fearing Ká:nien's sister Nonahkee may be in danger.

War! The Seven Years' War has begun, and the British and the French are at each other's throats - but John is focused on finding the British governor Warwick, whom he believes kidnapped his uncle Stuart.
John and Ká:nien head west, following Warwick's trail - and Nonahkee, Ká:nien's strong-willed sister, goes with them. Washington has promised help, but will his ships arrive in time?
Seeking revenge for Stuart's death, John and Ká:nien chase Warwick across the plains, into the vast, uncharted wilderness of the West.
In the snow-capped mountains far to the west of the colonies, John and Ká:nien finally catch up with Warwick - and his Boneguard minions.
John and Ká:nien learn why Warwick has traveled so far to the west. Can they stop the Circle's plan, or is it too late?
After the Revolutionary War, Americans pushed westward into the wilderness. It was a time of great change and technical progress - the dawn of the Industrial Age - and nothing would ever be the same.
With the other railroad companies beaten, Amelia is ready to continue the work ... until an unexpected event forces a change of plans.
Amelia follows the strange Frenchman Beaumont to his gold claim in the mountains, where a surprise - and an old friend - awaits.
Reunited with her granduncle Ká:nien and Major Cooper, Amelia is determined to pursue Beaumont -- and recover the Spanish gold her ancestors lost.

Learning that there may still be water from the Fountain of Youth hidden high in the Andes, Amelia and Ká:nien set sail for South America, where they find themselves caught up in the rebellions against Spain.
With Bolivar's guides, Amelia and Ká:nien head into the mountains, seeking the lost Inca in Pacamayo Valley -- but the army of the Circle of Ossus is right behind them!
Having forced their way through the storm, Amelia and Ká:nien find Pacamayo Valley at last - but the Circle is close behind.
The Circle has assembled in the Ossuary, their stronghold in Cuba. Will Amelia and Ká:nien be able to stop Beaumont, or will the Circle win at last?

language.string: %1s has %2d Trading Posts and will win in %3s

As you play through the Age of Empires III Story Mode missions you will receive Experience for almost everything you do. At the top of the Home City screen, you will see how much Experience you need to earn a new level for your Home City. When you earn a level, you will be able to visit this window between scenarios and pick a new Home City Card from one of the buildings.
Adds UI to show units, improvements and shipments in progress.
Adds UI for how long the game has lasted.
Adds UI for number of gatherers per resource type.
Adds UI to show the score of players in the game.
Adds UI to command your armies into different formations.
Automatically selects a whole formation with a single click
You are not a casual user if you turn this on.
Changes all player colors. You are blue. Allies are yellow. Enemies are red. Useful in games with many players or for players with some forms of colorblindness.
Adds tooltips for units and resources on the game map.
Delay before the world tooltips display
Delay before the game UI tooltips display.
Drag select will only select military units.
Adjust the scroll speed of your camera.
Controls the transparency of units obscured behind other objects.
Displays unit footprints on terrain like snow. Disabling may increase performance.
Display Objective Hints in the Story Mode missions.
Control the in-game zoom of the camera.
Allows you to receive in-game taunts from other players.
Adjust the quality of the game graphics.
High-poly models have greater detail but may reduce performance. Disabling may increase performance.
High-resolution textures have more detail, while low-resolution increases performance.
High quality settings will produce more detailed particle effects, like smoke and splashes, while low settings will increase performance.
Adjust the number of particles in the game.
Displays ballistic tracer effects. Disabling may increase performance.
Show shadows on units in the game.
High-quality settings provide more detailed shadows, while lower-quality settings increase performance.
Choose what shader model to use.
Displays object reflections in the water. Disabling may increase performance.
Display terrain detail objects like rocks and plants. Disabling may increase performance.
Age of Empires III can run in a window instead of full screen.
High resolutions have greater detail but may reduce performance.
High-bit depths provide increased color detail, while low-bit depths may increase performance.

Number of mipmap levels to skip.

Gamma correction setting for full screen.

Enhances bright areas of world. Disabling may increase performance.
Determines whether certain off-screen sounds can utilize special effect processing.

Each time you receive a Shipment you can visit the Home City and choose any of your available Cards below. You must be in the correct Age to send a Card.

Game Information: The Musketeer is an infantry unit with decent hitpoints, range and a good attack. They are one of the few units available to every Civilization and as such are one of the most common units in the game. Musketeers are a good all around unit, but not outstanding in any particular trait. Certain Civilizations, like the British, have unique improvements to Musketeers that make them even better than regular fully upgraded Musketeer infantry.

About Musketeers: Musketeers were an infantry soldier who stood in ranks for two and three men deep, taking turns firing while other ranks reloaded. Muskets were drilled and disciplined to stand as close as 80 yards away from an enemy firing right back at them. Musket balls ranged from about 1/2" in diameter to 3/4" in diameter. Until long guns with rifled barrels that could be fired more than once every two minutes were developed, muskets were the ranged weapon of choice for infantry. Muskets had a relatively short range and were wildly inaccurate.. Musketeers fought an awful lot like longbowmen, firing volley after volley in the direction of the enemy with no specific target. The barrage of lead was bound to hit something. A competent musketeer could fire 3 shots in a minute. Four times slower than a longbow and twice as fast as an early rifle.

Napoleon can be ambitious to the point of rudeness. He adapts his strategy to the situation, but prefers to attack with large armies of fully upgraded units, especially cavalry. He taunts his enemies frequently and may not follow his allies' lead.
Queen Elizabeth can be aloof, aristocratic and formal. She is a dependable if not overly warm ally. She understands the value of a strong economy and a versatile navy.

Queen Isabella of Castille is supportive bordering on flirtatious with her allies but mocks and chastises her enemies. She makes full use of the versatility of the Spanish army, but never leaves her colonies undefended. She is unlikely to take dangerous risks.

Ivan the Terrible is ruthless, sinister and threatening. He taunts enemy and ally alike. He likes to attack early and swarm his opponents with infantry and emphasizes large armies at the expense of technological development.

Maurice of Orange is all business. Every conversation is a transaction and every decision revolves around profit. He views war as a necessary part of business. He looks for Trade Routes when possible, but always defends his colonies.

Henry the Navigator is calculating and far-sighted. He emphasizes exploration and economic development over military dominance. He can take offense easily and can be something of a zealot when dealing with non-Portuguese.

Frederick the Great is proud and confident. He expresses regret when his men die in battle, but does not hesitate to use his entire military might to accomplish even the smallest task. Frederick will not neglect his economy, but believes in attacking aggressively.
Suleiman the Magnificent is scholarly and even-tempered. He balances colony development, trade, improvements and military. He is gracious to allies but may underestimate opponents.

Andes is a mountainous region with the warring factions starting dangerously close. A Trade Route with three Trading Post sites separates the teams. Four Inca settlements are on the far side of the map. Allying with all the Natives is potentially powerful.

California is a beautiful area along the Pacific Ocean. Towering redwoods line the shore, giving way first to mountains, then to the Mojave Desert to the east. Two Native settlements of Klamath and/or Nootka are on opposite map sides, and there are always four Trading Post sites along the Trade Route.

Settlements: Klamath, Nootka
Outlaws: Comanchero, Renegado

Northwest Territory is a green and rainy region along the Pacific Coast of North America. Resources are plentiful, and Klamath and Nootka villages can be found nestled among the trees. Control the crossings and the resource-rich region across the main river to ensure victory.
Grants archers a new attack against buildings using flaming arrows.

Traditional armor and reckless courage enable your cavalry to do bonus damage to enemy artillery.
All siege weapon armor increased, making them far more resistant to ranged fire.

Hispaniola: a large island surrounded by warm tropical seas.

Settlements: Caribs
Outlaws: Pirate

Surrounded by sea, Hispaniola promises conflict on both land and water. Inland, Carib tribes live in the jungles, around the base of an impassable mountain.\n \nExtra starting crates of Food will help you jump start your early economy. Whales in the western bay are a strategic secondary source of Coin.

A Trading Post on this trading route will yield one Native Villager each time the Travois passes it. This may be a useful way to expand your town.
Perhaps the reports about the Mohawk and Seneca allying with the British have been exaggerated.
Looks like you've got a bit of fight left in you, uncle.
We're here to help if we can, war chief.
We'll have to decide how many of our villagers should work on the community plaza, and how many should be gathering and building.
I can hear war drums across the river. We need a strategy, and soon.
We should bring plenty of cavalry when we attack the Seneca.
The Mohawk town center has been destroyed. Mission accomplished!
The Seneca town center is down. Mission accomplished!
We should journey to the Oneida village.
I know this region well. I used to hunt here as a boy.
The Mohawk copper mines are far from their village. Attacking the miners would be a good way to slow their economy.
The more villagers that dance at the Community Plaza, the better.
These are the Mohawk copper mines.
Greetings, Nathaniel. We are being raided by two tribes across the river.
We accept your help in our battle.
The Mohawk live to the northeast. The Seneca live to the northwest.
Battles between tribes are often decided by a swift show of force. If we destroy one tribe's town center, the other tribe will stop fighting as well.
We should focus our attacks on one tribe while defending our own village.
You are right. But we have learned that the Seneca tribe is vulnerable to attacks by cavalry.
Our villagers must join the war dance at the Community Plaza.
Perhaps the reports about the Mohawk and Seneca allying with the British have been exaggerated.
The war party has been assembled.
Another settler has joined us at our trading post!
We've got to destroy the stockade holding my mother before the Mohawk become too strong to defeat.
You're a fool, Kuechler - you and the Mohawks you've tricked into joining you.
We must protect them as they work to expand our military strength.
There are two trading post sites. One has already been claimed by the Mohawks, but we can change that.
Each time a travois passes our trading post, a new villager will join us.
Our base has no villagers. To build and expand we must free villagers being held captive by the Mohawk and their Hessian allies.
There are other villagers being held. The more we free, the faster we can expand our base.
We should kill more of the enemy's villagers while we continue to rescue more of our own.
The locals fight well, with Hessian leadership.
The Mohawks have allowed some of our prisoners to be freed. I should have stationed more of my mercenaries at that pen.
The Natives stand no chance against trained mercenaries.
The Native woman is my prisoner and she shall remain so.
Side with Oneida, boy, and be wiped out with them.
A mix of spruce trees. Harvest for Wood.

Hold Breed's Hill until reinforcements arrive.
Protect the redoubt on Breed's Hill.

You will lose if British troops reach the redoubt, and you have no soldiers of your own nearby. The British will be attacking Breed's Hill from different angles. Keep troops in the redoubt to defend against land attacks.
Cross the Delaware River and strike terror into the hearts of the British.
Cross the Delaware River and destroy the Hessian tents.
Light a signal fire at the two flagged locations.
Destroy Cornwallis' rear guard stationed in Princeton.
The Hessians are camped in Trenton. Their patrol from tent to tent. Watch where the patrol goes and avoid it, then sneak in and destroy the tents.
Use Nathaniel to build a signal fire at each of the flagged locations. The fires will fool Cornwallis into thinking your army has camped and lure him out of Princeton.
Your group of colonial militia is too small to take on Cornwallis' army. You can, however, flank the main group heading for Trenton and strike at the smaller rear guard still stationed in Princeton.
Better War Chief Strike attack and improves the War Chief's hitpoints by 20%.
Better War Chief Strike attack and improves the War Chief's hitpoints by 30%.
Better War Chief Strike attack and improves the War Chief's hitpoints by 40%.
Best War Chief Strike attack and improves the War Chief's hitpoints by 50%.
+10% War/Nobles' Hut att/hp and 1 War Hut Travois.
1 Farm Travois and +10% to Farm and Estate gather rate.
2 Farm Travois and +10% to Farm and Estate gather rate.
2 Farm Travois and +15% to Farm and Estate gather rate.
2 Farm Travois and +20% to Farm and Estate gather rate.
Zapotec warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
+10% War/Nobles' Hut att/hp and 2 Nobles Hut Travois.
+30% War/Nobles' Hut att/hp and 2 Nobles Hut Travois.

Get some more men to the redoubt.
We have to hold it until Ward's men arrive.
Use the guns to take out the ships.
We need more troops defending the redoubt. If it falls, we've lost.
Watch for soldiers flanking the front.
We've held off the British! Everyone fall back!
The British have taken the redoubt. We've lost!
Steady, men. We've got to hold on to the redoubt.
General Ward's men will be in place soon.
The British are coming across from Boston Harbor.
British ships are trying to attack our flanks.
British forces have captured the western gun.
The eastern gun has been captured.
General Ward's men are in place.
Another British ship is coming in from Boston.
We've captured the Hessian garrison here in Trenton.
It's working. Cornwallis is on his way here from Princeton.
Cornwallis is sending a patrol back to Princeton. Let's give them a warm welcome.
These people are loyal to the cause. They will help us to keep an eye on Cornwallis' army.
The British are holding prisoners on those ships. We should destroy them and free the prisoners.
The Hessians have a falconet in that garrison. We should be able to capture it.
Cornwallis has heard the fighting. He's sending a patrol to investigate.
Be careful of the patrol around Trenton.
Since the colonials are in retreat, we will only have one patrol tonight.
It sounds like the Hessians are enjoying the celebration.
If we can avoid patrols and take out the tents in Trenton, we should catch them off guard.
We don't have the manpower to take on his main army.
Build some fires to trick Cornwallis into thinking we've made camp for the night.
Excellent. Move out and attack his rear guard.
Take out the rear guard now!
The rear guard in Princeton has been destroyed.
Early automatic-fire weapon. Better against infantry than buildings.
Revolt, and become a new nation!
My father Nathaniel Black was a hero of the American Revolution, who fought with the colonial army at Bunker Hill, Trenton and Saratoga...
...and he was there at the end, at Yorktown.
But his story begins six years earlier, in his village where he had grown up.
The six nations of the Confederacy split apart as the fires of the American Revolution spread northward.
Nathaniel's world would never be the same.
So the Seneca have joined with the Mohawk?
Yes. Both tribes think the British will protect them.
This is a white man's war. We must counsel the Seneca and the Mohawk to stay out of the fight.
Uncle Ká:nien, if we don't choose a side, one will be chosen for us. We must defend our homes.
It's not a matter for young warriors to decide.
No more, Nathaniel. You will accompany me to the villages of our brothers. You will be silent. You will learn.
Colonel Kuechler, here are the captives the Mohawk took from the Oneida village.
How many warriors can your village muster?
You will know when they come for your head.
Do not mistake me for some soft Englishman.
You may know how to make war against your own kind, but you face Hessians now.
My orders are to cleanse these woods of rebels. If your people get in my way, they die.
The six nation Confederacy was broken.
Some joined the British, while others, helped the colonial cause.
Whether he was driven by a desire to live up to his father John's legacy, or he simply wanted to learn more about the outside world, I never knew.
When the call went out for militia volunteers, Nathaniel and other young men from the frontier headed south, to Boston...
I'm Captain Nathaniel Black. Where are we needed?
The British have landed near Breed's Hill - follow me!
In the early days of the Revolution, the Americans were always on the defensive - pushed out of Boston, out of New York.
George Washington took command of the colonials, determined to make a real army out of ragtag militiamen.
But even Washington's leadership could not stop the British tide.
By December of 1776, the Americans had been pushed back across the Delaware to McKonkey's Ferry.
It was there my father's militia joined them.
General Washington...I'm honored to meet you, sir.
The honor is mine, Captain Black. Your father John was a good man.
I would be pleased to have you think the same of me one day.
I'm sorry we missed the fight in New York.
Perhaps you would have changed the outcome.
But you're here in time to help us turn the tide. The Hessian garrison has settled into their winter quarters in Trenton.
Yes. They're camped right across the Delaware.
I've got unfinished business with the Hessians.
Good. Let's give them a holiday to remember.
Capture the cannon at the Hessian Garrison
Find and destroy the Hessian base.
Find and destroy the second Hessian base.
Blast a path through the main Hessian base.
Pursue and destroy Kuechler's army before it destroys the Morristown Capitol building.
Scouts report the Hessian base may be to the north.
The second Hessian base is thought to be located beyond the swamps to the northeast.
Artillery is the best weapon to use to knock down buildings and walls.
The swift cavalry units that Washington gave you may be the most effective way to attack Kuechler's army in time.
Kuechler may be defeated by a concerted attack.
Destroy all enemy Barracks. Do not let four Mining Camps be destroyed.
Allow no Trading Posts to be destroyed.
Allow no Mining Camps to be destroyed.

You may need to train many military units and divide them into two or three armies. Consider stationing your armies where they can quickly respond to attacks on your Mining Camps and main base. Change your orders in your Trading Posts to receive those resources you most need.
To defend all of your Trading Posts may require you to station several armies in different places around the map.
To defend all of your Mining Camps may require you to station several armies strategically around the map.
Earn the trust of the Lakota.
Earn 300 Experience Points for each Lakota warrior prisoner returned to the flagged area in the Lakota village.
Earn 100 Experience Points for each crate of resources gathered.
Earn 2,000 Experience Points for rescuing the Lakota War Chief and returning him to the flagged area in the Lakota village.
Earn 150 Experience Points for each Outlaw killed.
Earn 1,000 Experience Points for building a Trading Post on the trade route.

Completing secondary objectives will help you reach your primary objective. You cannot train Settlers from your Town Center. However, your Miners and any Settlers you send from your Home City can gather from any resource crates you find or steal.
Sheriff Holme may be hiding somewhere in the caves to the northwest.

Lakota prisoners are being held at different locations around the map. After you free a prisoner from a stockade, you must bring him to the flagged area in the light blue Lakota village to collect Experience Points for the rescue.
Some crates of resources are guarded. Kill the guards before sending in your Miners to gather from them.

There may be a back route through the canyons near the Sheriff's base, through which the Lakota War Chief can be more easily rescued. After you free the Lakota War Chief from the stockade, you must bring him to the flagged area in the light blue Lakota village to collect experience for the rescue.
Bring plenty of soldiers when fighting bandits.
There may be a Trading Post socket to the northeast of your base.
Storage building for ammunition and weapons.
Attack and hitpoints increased for Aennas & Tomahawks. Requires Community Plaza.
Intensive Zapotec battle training increases hand infantry damage.
Using Zapotec agricultural methods, your Villagers gather from Berry Bushes, Mills, Farms, Estates, Cherry Orchards, and Rice Paddies faster.
Mountain-dwelling allies of the Zapotec provide you with approximately 100 high-altitude Wood in crates for every 2 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.
Using Cheyenne methods, you are able to mount your cavalry more quickly, which trains them faster.
A herd of 12 Bison appears at your Home City Gather Point.
The Huron Fishing Wedding ritual boosts your Fishing Boat gather rate.
The Huron Sun Cult increases the number of Huron Mantlets you can train.
The Huron mercantile monopoly permits you to get approximately 1 Mantlet for every 2 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.
Wall hitpoints greatly increased. Requires Community Plaza.
The Cheyenne thirst for revenge! Cheyenne warriors do additional damage to enemy cavalry.
The Apache secrets of endurance improve all your military's speed.
The Apache tribe knows how to utilize cactus for food, drink, and fiber, improving Settler speed and hit points.
Apache raiding tactics enable your Apache warriors to inflict far more damage on enemy Settlers.
Mapuche warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Mapuche warrior attack and hitpoints increased.
Klamath tactical skill enables your Klamath warriors to inflict far more damage.
It's the early fall Huckleberry Feast! You get approximately 100 Food in crates for every 3 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.
Klamath dedication to labor and ownership causes all your Villagers to gather slightly more quickly.
Skilled Navajo workers make your goods more valuable, increasing your Coin gather rate across the board.
Navajo sheep raising skills let your herd animals fatten much more quickly on a Livestock Pen, Farm, Village, Shrine, and Sacred Field.
Navajo weaving talent gives all your soldiers superior garb, granting them all more hitpoints.
Protect your cannons to take down the two enemy fortifications.
Use the Covered Wagon to construct a Town Center.
Build up your town and train an army to take out the Yorktown Town Center.
Sophisticated Mapuche legal system strengthens your social structure and lowers the Coin cost of your units.
As the York River towers are destroyed the French will send you more ships. Three Petards are needed to take down each tower.
Siege and many troops will be needed to take destroy the Redoubt Cannons.
The approach of dawn temporarily reveals all enemies and treasures on the map. Preparedness enables your Axe Riders to loot treasures and gain greater resource rewards from them.
Formal European recognition of the Mapuche nation provides approximately 100 Coin in crates for every 2 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.
Mapuche guerrilla techniques make your hand infantry even more deadly against buildings.
"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."
"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."
"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."
"These are our lands, but we will permit you to build a Trading Post here to forge an alliance between our people."
The villagers near Charlestown have offered to help us.
We need to reinforce Breed's Hill and hold it until Ward's men arrive.
Increases Warchief's pets' hitpoint and sends 1 pet bear
Great Heart: all nearby troops have their hit points boosted. Passive ability.
The mysterious Unknown! Snow or desert, land or water, Trade Routes or Natives or both - you never quite know what you're going to get. Expect the unexpected!
General Cornwallis is using the Capitol in Trenton as a headquarters for his army. Use the help from the people of Princeton to build up an army and destroy this valuable target.
I thought we were going to die on those ships. Thank you.
Now that the rear guard has been destroyed, the people are offering their help.
Get more soldiers ready. Put everything we have into destroying that town center.
At the dawn of the American Revolution, the nations of the Haudenosaunee (referred to as the Iroquois Confederacy by European settlers) faced their greatest challenge.
Nonahkee has been kidnapped! Nathaniel and Ká:nien race to her rescue, hoping to discover the identity of her captors.
Nonahkee has been rescued, but her reunion with her son Nathaniel will be a brief one...
In the early days of the Revolution, the colonials were pushed back time and time again - until Washington took command.
The British army's summer push down the Hudson River Valley seemed unstoppable - but their supply lines were thinly stretched.
A hard winter awaited the colonial army at Valley Forge...but Nathaniel's militia was there to help.
Throughout the war, Colonel Kuechler eluded Nathaniel - until finally, they would face off near Morristown.
When the French entered the war on the American side, the colonists were finally able to throw off Britain's yoke.
Light infantry with low hitpoints, but a long-ranged attack. Good against infantry.
Automatically generates units of your choice.
Put them to work gathering resources, and keep our men in the redoubt.
We'll need to train more soldiers if we're going to hold off the British.
The British will be attacking soon.
Sir! Lookouts report the British are about three minutes away.
British troops have been spotted in Boston. They'll be here any minute.
Generates resources or artillery automatically. Configure it to produce different things. Can only be sent from the Home City.
We need to take out their outposts to clear an area for our forward base.
Good work, men. Supplies have arrived for Washington's army. Let's set up our town center and get to work right away.
The French have sent word that they have arrived to assist us.
This base will do just fine. Train an army and drive the British from Yorktown!
The redoubts will need to be destroyed before we can hope to penetrate Yorktown.
All of the outposts along the river must be destroyed for more of the French Navy to arrive.
Take these petards and destroy the British outposts along the river.
The French Navy is waiting out in the Atlantic. Once the York river is safe we will be able to attack.
We can send more ships if more outposts are destroyed.
The men won't last long working out in this cold.
The bakers in town will give us food, though it won't be free.
Money shouldn't be an issue. I'm sure my grandchildren will understand...
We'll just have to make sure we avoid British patrols.
Perhaps these Haudenosaunee can help us out.
Get that food cart back to the camp.
Watch out for British patrols while you're heading back to Valley Forge.
We have enough food. Get those huts built.
General, the food stores are full!
We'll never last the winter in these tents. We need to get the men busy building proper quarters.
Good. Now we'll need to concentrate on getting enough food to feed the troops.
The colonial army has no money right now.
Maybe some of the local tribes have some food they can give us.
Get back to the fires if it gets too cold.
Excellent work everyone. The colonial army has survived to fight another day.
We have barely enough supplies for our own survival.
But perhaps some of our people can help out.
We have no food to spare, but my people will hunt for you.
Yes, these should do nicely, General.
Kuechler does have a small base here. Let's destroy it.
Quick! We must use the route he's shown us to reach Kuechler's siege army!
Kuechler's siege army is on the move!
Kuechler's siege army is halfway to Morristown.
Kuechler's army has begun to siege Morristown.
Kuechler's siege army is smashing its way east through Morristown.
We've got to stop them before they destroy the Morristown capitol!
Cavalry are the most effective units against artillery.
Better watch our flanks; Kuechler knows these swamps better than we do.
Kuechler's troops are attacking our base through a southeast route.
I'm not sure what Kuechler is up to on our north flank, but I don't want another surprise like we had at Bound Brook.
These artillery pieces from my cannonworks should help take care of whatever you find up there.
As you destroy Hessian buildings I will supply you with additional artillery units.
Here are more artillery units to help you, Nathaniel.
Here is another artillery piece, Nathaniel.
Kuechler has begun to attack the capitol! You must destroy his siege army!
Nathaniel, here are my swiftest cavalry. Use them to help stop Kuechler!
You will never stop me in time!
No - I will not be defeated by you! NO!
The Hessians have held me prisoner - thank you for rescuing me.
The Hessian's main base is farther north. He has been working secretly to assemble a large siege army.
Colonel Kuechler plans to advance with his siege army to Morristown on a secret path through a swamp west of here. He means to destroy the capitol!
I will show you the only route to pursue Kuechler's siege army before he destroys the capitol.
You've done it! Kuechler and his Hessians are defeated.
Perform a Victory Ceremony to boost unit hit points.
Your Villagers are performing a Victory Ceremony to boost unit hitpoints.\nCurrent Benefit:\n{danceDescription}
Perform a Green Corn Ceremony to boost unit speed.
Your Villagers are performing a Green Corn Ceremony to boost unit speed.\nCurrent Benefit:\n{danceDescription}
Perform a Town Ceremony to increase building hitpoints and attack.
Your Villagers are performing a Town Ceremony to increase building hitpoints and attack.\nCurrent Benefit:\n{danceDescription}
The food and wood here are scarce. We'll have to rely on our trading posts.
The scouts report bandits and rival miners are willing to fight for control of these hills.
We must protect the mining camps!
We've destroyed an enemy barracks - good work.
That war hut has been destroyed.
One of our trading posts is under attack!
We've done it! We've taken out every barracks in the Black Hills.
We can't afford to lose too many more trading posts.
You know what's bad about gold? It attracts flies.
The vermin 'round here want to destroy the mining camps.
Your job is to protect the mining camps, while taking out their barracks.
They've destroyed one of our mining camps!
Another mining camp has been destroyed.
You'll never make deputy fighting like that.
You allowed three mining camps to be destroyed. Never send a boy to do a man's job.
Light artillery. Better against infantry than buildings.
A falconet that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A mortar that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A cannon that doesn't belong to you - yet.
A rocket that doesn't belong to you - yet.
My scouts report Colonel Kuechler's Hessians are moving on our north flank.
Intercept him before he cuts our supply line.
I knew you were the man for the job.
This war, this revolution - it's larger than any one man.
I know Kuechler has wronged you personally.
But your father's desire for revenge led him to his death.
General Washington, my father gave his life to protect the colonies. I would do the same, without hesitation.
Your enlistment is up next month. You could go back home to your family.
My place is with the Colonial Army until our nation is free.
I'll fight at your side until the war is won.
After the battles at Trenton and Princeton, Nathaniel's militia was sent north, into the wilderness along the Canadian border.
His men skirmished with the British up and down the Hudson Valley throughout the spring.
But the fighting was indecisive until late summer, near Saratoga.
There's the British column. They're headed to Albany.
Captain...if they get that far, they'll cut our army in two.
Send scouts to mark their route. We'll whittle them down and force them to fight here.
After Colonel Kuechler's death, Nathaniel kept his promise to Washington.
And he was there at the end, at Yorktown in 1781, face to face with the redcoats for the last time.
Saratoga was a great victory, but there were many trials ahead.
The British and the Hessians pushed back hard, defeating the Americans at Brandywine and Germantown.
In December, the colonial army retreated to its winter camp at Valley Forge and settled in to wait for spring.
General, we can't sit here all winter. The men will starve.
We have no choice. We must reorganize and refit.
Soon we'll face Cornwallis' army head-on. The new recruits need training.
They need food more than training.
I can find my way through enemy lines and bring back the supplies we need.
An excellent plan, but a dangerous one, Captain. Be careful.
War Rifle attack and hitpoints increased.
Axe Rider attack and hitpoints increased.
Axe Rider attack and hitpoints increased.
Tashunke Prowler attack and hitpoints increased.
Coup Rider attack and hitpoints increased.

Canoe and War Canoe attack increased.

A successful Maple Festival provides you with approximately 500 Coin for every 10 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.
A successful New Year Festival provides you with 2000 Experience Points.
Knowledge of the surrounding woodlands provides you with approximately 500 Wood for every 10 minutes of game length, up to 30 minutes.

Call to war! Fifteen Tomahawks arrive at your Home City Gather Point.

Stand Ground. Your units will assume a completely defensive posture and not move around the map.

Painted Desert: Open desert with plentiful resources but no trade route.

Settlements: Apache, Navajo
Outlaws: Comanchero, Pistolero

Painted Desert is a lonely open range with scattered mesas and rich ore deposits. Hunting is plentiful, but Wood is a little scarcer. Lost cows can also be found wandering among the mesas. Four Apache and Navajo villages line the center of the map.
Show/Hide Games which can not accept new players
Show/Hide games based on whether you meet the Home City type and level requirements
Turn on to disable the detailed player communication UI in team games.

You cannot afford to break your Treaty.

You cannot delete a Home City you are currently viewing
No XP will be awarded for this game.
Handicap, Cheats, and Custom Maps must be disabled.
There must be at least two human players.
XP will be awarded for this game.
